We ordered about 7 dishes (although we were not that hungry) but ended up eating it all. Our favorites were chicken lollipops and chicken chops. We had couple cocktails first, they were a little weak but when our server heard about it he took care of it right away and they were strong enough. One complaint perhaps is their signature martinis are sort of on the sweet side and I rather prefer a more savory taste. Overall, it was a fantastic place to eat.

HvLr_CWOQPhFJXnf-r1KTQ.text: Visiting London for a few days and decided to give Amaya a try based on what I read online. Based on my experience I can only conclude that the unabashedly glowing reviews are from non-vegetarians or from customers who have never stepped out of Belgravia. The vegetarian platter was nothing but a random mis-match of leftovers with most creations badly missing the mark. Transport Amaya to the San Francisco Bay Area and you will find an empty spot in less than a year. Pretention does not take you very far in the US.

5qEzMHnMsZYNSoDuPiRSTw.text: Underwhelming.  We went here on a friend's enthusiastic recommendation (and really, I tried to like it!), but ultimately found the food to be bland and uninspired, the atmosphere overly-trendy and impersonal, and the cost a little high for the quality.  While I appreciate the idea of Indian tapas (and I think it would be a fantastic place for drinks and appetizers), in reality, I was left with a craving for something heartier and more traditional.

cPwo5wteBRd-ee4Vvecxnw.text: I've been to Amaya twice. The first time was a sure fire 5 star rating. The second visit would have been a 3 to 4 star. Why? The food wasn't quite as good the second time round, and for the price tag you'd really expect the best. The food is Indian tapas which is a pretty neat concept. This of course means you're driven to ordering a bit of everything. Some of the highlights are the lamb cutlets, the broccoli and yoghurt, the tandoori chicken and the chicken biryani (which was amazing the first time round, not so good the second time). The cocktails are amazing. I would highly recommend getting there a bit early and sampling one or two. They do a great chilli Martini (or they did the last time I went). The ambiance is decadent (as you'd expect for the area). I like the fact you can see what's gong on in the kitchen, it adds a buzz and energy to a place that could be stiff in other circumstances. Will I go back? Well it really is pricey, so pricey that you need to be prepared to have a big hole in your wallet when you leave, especially if you go to town on the 'tapas' and cocktails. Perhaps I will if I win the lottery. I kind of wish they hadn't changed their chef though.

T2AEKGoiT6yhR5dokgDVhA.text: Hometown favorite for sure.  Anyone visiting who wants an experience, should seriously consider dining here.  Food is excellent, service is stellar. Very highly recommended.

pChBmokhJgSTVUUqIQux7A.text: This is not your typical curry house. Trendy high end indian cuisine and worth the extra money. You need a reservation as well or you will probably sit at a communal table. We ordered the sampler for 2 and it was great. Lots of food and mostly things you would not normally order. Great service as well.

PutSvO-ZvWATRK6vaEuUjA.text: Michelin must in London!  This restaurant is located in the very swanky area of Belgravia, home to London's VIP's.  This is not the Indian cuisine you're likely to expect, but the flavors and service do not dissapoint.  I would suggest the tasting menu to maximize your first visit, it's a nice showing of the menu overall.

Vl3s9GPNZ5RjstllRbmTJg.text: Good food but nothing special... loved the modern atmospere and enjoyed looking at chefs preparing the salads and grilling... the service was excellent, Food is okay but not so flavorful like usual indian cuisine... Very expensive we were 2 and our bill was 100 pounds (we only ordered 3 half portion starters) 1 main course and 1 dessert plus water.Although I have enjoyed the experience, but I will not go there again because I have seen it, but I will recommend if you want to have good time rather than good food.

n41b4m0zH1Cm7U8qeazIkA.text: I ate here once before catching a show in the West End and had a wondeful experience.  The food is really Indian Fusion, the chefs do a incredible job of blending traditional Indian spcies into their dishes.  The plates are small but succulent, and the decor lends itself to a very classy dining experience.  It's a great place to impress a date.

ujasW1YSUqRj2Lb8E1GBbw.text: Wow what an experience! We ended 2010 on a high at Amaya. Very chic interior and an extractor fan that's actually working! The staff was nicely dressed, polite and sure knew what they were doing. We even got a very entertaining lecture on champagne. The food was absolutely spot on. Not the usual 'curry' but a tapas style way of eating which means you really get an experience rather than a meal. We all ordered something and ended up eating our way through the whole range of food from the venison to the grouper. And don't get me started on the lamb what a feast. I am not one to use a lot of superlatives, but this was definitely the best food experience of 2010. I sure hope they can keep up the high expectations and we'll come back for more.

CWpXs5ijN0yfZ1zJsOEfeg.text: Amaya is one of London's top newish restaurants (2004). The creation of Amaya exemplifies the typical British mentality of appreciating cultures from a far and marketing them as much as possible. Many British are also known as having an adventure instinct, maybe because they once explored the world as much as anyone founded all dem colonies and shizzle, or maybe its simply because British people are a very curious bunch... maybe I shouldn't make the Brits into an anthropology project...Anyway, London's advancements lead to an upscale Indian restaurant as progressive as Obama's plans.  As you have read, Amaya is officially a tapas restaurant but if you are the type of Brit who hangs out in Knighsbridge, and goes to Amaya on a business meeting you are probably having the company write it off.Therefore, you certainly do not order tapas style as someone who doesn't want to spend £££ would (only get one appetizer sized dish each). No, you order as the waitress recommends:A full meal for everyone at your table. That means a great amount of dishes. Just a blur and swirl of the most exotic food that may ever be put in front of you in your life. Amaya's policy is that you order what you want when you want but whatever comes out first, they will serve it then and there. Now, Erase every perception in your mind of Indian food: a plate of rice, a little container of a chicken dish with some sauce, a basket of naan. Right, throw that all in a rubbish bin when you walk in to Amaya and except: Tiger Prawns on a kabob stick, the most sizzling sauces, a blend of masala you've never had, all sorts of naan breads. It's the mecca of that thin line between Brits being British London being London and Indian food at its impeccable prime to the taste buds of people living in London. Find yourself there? You must try Amaya! The Beautiful People Ranking: 8/10As I said, expect a lot of business men but a certain swankier London businessmen type who wears a fitted suite and drives a BMW. Girls who aren't especially dressed to the nines but are European beautiful, you'll see couples, fancies, and misc

oxqhsKa5TUePUzMTYUfJZg.text: I love Amaya. This place is tapas style Indian dining. The food has a very creative touch to it while sticking to the the traditional Indian ingredients. The chicken dishes are absolutely amazing! Go try it, you won't be disappointed at all!

496jUxD-SpatVJvRTFCEkA.text: Ok get your credit card ready for some delicious food! Still salivating over a monk fish curry kebab we had last time. We try to order everything and share the tastes - love the spices and smells emanating from the gorgeous open kitchen. Wine list is well designed to pair with the food. Love the location, great vibe, excellent food.

pzmK5peIMXYF_U7kRCJRUw.text: Did the tasting menu which was interesting.  We received a wide range of indian dishes to try out.  I think my only wish was that the food that we actually like came in larger portions.  Beautiful atmosphere and great drinks.

07NTg3lZlfJZ-WF_Zr6eyg.text: On entering you are taken by the rather swish interior, which is what one would expect with it being located in Knightsbridge. I was taken here on a date (quite sometime ago). I tried a variety of cocktails and dishes on the menu - the food was delicious and the service superb. Although, my date at the time was always complaining that the naan breads weren't warm enough or glistening? - hmmm, I was surprised that the waitor resisted the temptation to lamp him one :-) If you're looking to dine for a special occassion or want to impress a date, then I'd recommend Amaya.

ICc00TdRaxaQxL-IjQZ44A.text: yummm best sikh kebob in london

cj6oXoCGEYl6VV3bFHaYrQ.text: totally overpriced...shrimp tandoori is the best thing they have, lamb curry is good. chicken satay is good. not a great place for vegetarians though, you will starve! drinks not so good. dessert terrible. ambiance is nice. service is strange. overpriced, completely overpriced. lots of better indian spots in london, don't waste your money.

xbA6WsZHVAao_haOx88KyA.text: Fantastic fresh Indian delicacies with a bit of a nouveau/fusion touch. They have small plates to maximise the dishes experienced. Food is excellent and drinks are also nice. I had the annar, which was a pomegranate martini. I think the place is slightly overpriced for what it is. My friend booked it through her concierge on a Sunday evening from a nice hotel and there was much fuss to get a booking for two but when we got there plenty of tables were idle. Not sure what the fuss was about.Service was good and place has a nice chill ambiance. Not sure I'd go back often but nice for once in a while nouveau Indian food.

0sz6e5eEA-6szEBglLspNw.text: One of the best Indian restaurants out there and completely on par with fine dining in Mumbai and Delhi.  I can't rave about this place enough as a truly amazing culinary experience. Think multi-course, delicate plates and excellent pairing.  The ambiance is nice, but not 'the coolest place ever' like a Hakesaan or Zuma, but the open-kitchen is a great touch and you can see all the food being prepared, which is quite a show as it is all meticulously done.If you're looking for traditional sag paneer, dal, naan and curries, this is not the place to go -- you can go to any one of the countless, fantastic run-of-the mill Indian places.  Amaya is different.  Every spice, leaf, nut and garnish is perfectly placed and calculated so that each bite is a complete piece of the dish.I wanted to go for the veg tasting menu, but the waiter said it would take 4 hours to complete!  If you have the time, this is always the best way to go at a place like this.  They have 3 or 4 tasting menus: meat, vegetarian and fish, and maybe a chef's choice but I can't remember.  I can't remember exactly what I had as it was a while back and I must have been in a sensory-overload haze, but I remember it all to be amazing.  Plus, great cocktails too!  If you love Indian, or have never had Indian outside a north-Indian curry restaurant, please give this place a shot and I promise you will be enlightened.

oQsNdguRxL4eUDMEK7pAwA.text: I was told by many that I must try Indian food in London.   Armed with some recs (Mint Leaf was another top choice, to be saved for the next trip), we eventually decided on Amaya.Best Indian restaurant ever. Here is why:1.  The food was amazing-from the lamb to chicken tikka to the paneer to the fish dishes, nothing disappointed.  Well, except my poor choice in insisting that I needed to order rice (at 4 quid a bowl, no less).  Full disclosure:  Despite being a desi, I can't handle very spicy Indian food.  So I thought I needed rice to make the spicy food more tolerable for me.  And truth be told,  I do like rice!  I was so wrong-the spice combos in all the dishes were so delectable, as were the powders.2.  No curry, even in the dishes that traditionally have curries.2.  Indian tapas!  Second generation Indian at its most sophisticated.3.  Elegant, sleek interior and fun atmosphere-still crowded at 10:30 pm on a weekday night.I want to come back and try the vegetarian and meat tasting menus.  Or just to have one more dish.

BNmnerO_0dlqD-X1MCxo4g.text: This is one of my favorite Indian Creative/Fusion restaurants.  It is a very classy restaurant with wonderful decor and a chic feel.  The food is almost like Indian tapas.  Small portions but fantastic food, every single dish!  I usually order about 4 to 5 different dishes per person and drink about 2 glasses of wine there, which costs an average of 60-70 quids per person.  It is expensive, very expensive.  But once every few months, I am happy to splurge.The grilled seafood items are just wonderful.  The tiger prawns and the monk fish are my absolute favorites.

vESQhtoZtwfQXBVjmTtHnQ.text: For US visitors, this is a "concept" restaurant.  The "concept" is grilled Indian. It's loud, slick and hip. One wouldn't blink if this was plucked directly from Scottsdale, or LA.  It's ok as a scene if that's what you seek, but far better indian food can be had elsewhere.

JcELYEJwRk97TK8nYsIycg.text: Definitely not your run of the mill Indian local...far from it... It's an upmarket restaurant in every sense; prices, decor, setting, location and food presentation all reflect this. If you want to limit a potentially high bill try lunching here. You can opt for a set meal with lots of enticing smaller portions of taste-bud-tingling fare. Or if you want something light and different I highly recommend the radicchio salad with goat cheese and mandarin - not traditionally Indian but certainly delicious. Many dishes are available in two sizes. There's a creative and varied choice of non-alcoholic cocktails. The service is very attentive and responsive.

1zz3lQ_cvFScTLlP0RgdSQ.text: Fantastic experience!  All evening grazing on course after delectable course of nouveau Indian, tapas-style foods.  Fragrant, savory spiced dishes of every variety, traditional choices served with non-traditional flair.  We had a great waiter, very patient And attentive.  Sat near enough the kitchen that fresh new aromas wafted over us all evening long.  Perfectly paced delivery ensured we were always satisfied, never stuffed.  Absolutely amazing atmosphere, cuisine and service -- with the appropriately astronomic price tag to go with it.  Worth every rupee.

T2BwFuZd5HYbmDYn8fypig.text: Amaya is the high end offering of the Masala World group, the owners of Masala Zone and Veeraswamy.The first thing that had struck me about Amaya, even before i had visited it for the first time, was the following line from their website."Amaya is a casual and joyous restaurant where people can relax and eat with their fingers if they wish"Eat with my fingers !!! In Knightsbridge !!! Are you kidding me ?But i understood, within minutes after walking in,why they could make this statement. Their menu does not have a single dish with gravy. An Indian restaurant totally devoid of curry. How many times have you seen that ? The only liquid item in the menu was dal.This is a grill house par excellence. The kebabs are at least as good as anywhere else in London, and to give Amaya the edge, it has a number of starters in their menu that you won't find anywhere else. Which other Indian restaurant serves venison kebab ? (strongly recommended btw). I tried the ground peanut and rose petal powders with the food ... it really amplified the taste.The wine list is good. Though i am not an expert, but i think i chose something that goes well with dry meat :)The place is expensive, but totally worth every pound of the bill. I could have cut corners and spent £20 less, but then what would have been the point of going to amaya ?

mGbmTy_JFrgrDdGWB-Xgvg.text: I went to Amaya for lunch one day, pretty much as a fluke, and I was absolutely delighted. It's a large restaurant, with a nice warm bar by the door, lots of natural light and cooking happening on the far walls. There is also an extensive specialty drink list, both alcoholic and non--I'll have to go back to try some out--and everything on the menu looked so good, I ended up getting a veritable veggie feast. My meal started with a slightly spicy green mango and papaya salad, which I really enjoyed. Once I was done with the salad, though, it seemed like the dishes just kept coming out! There was some paneer tikka, which is always one of my favorites, and a great fig and vegetable patty and some sweet potatoes with sauce. There was also some broccoli with a yogurt sauce, which was my least favorite dish  the broccoli was a bit overcooked and it was a much larger quantity than any of the other dishes, which was just incongruous and unappetizing to look at. There were some stuffed little chilies that I really liked, which were surprisingly sweet, no hot, and there was a veggie roll of some sort. The dishes were all served with a side of chutneys--one rhubarb and one tomato, which were both really delicious, and a peanutty spice powder and a rose and lavender powder, which was wonderful. All the dishes were presented really beautifully as well, on plates of various shapes in white ceramic and glass. There was also some grilled mango and a sort of passionfruit smoothie for dessert, which were nice and refreshing. Overall, a very extravagant lunch, but a fantastic, relaxing experience. It was nice to feel welcomed and taken care of as a single diner. I can't wait to go back for dinner and to bring friends along to share.

kriaLCaMMV4JfdWNXNEdsw.text: Excellent and creative, fresh Indian food. The chef creates an inspiring menu of Indian food that blends flavors from around India and elsewhere to make a very modern and delicious cuisine. I highly recommend the tandoori black pepper chicken and the Kerala biryani. They have also added some creatively refreshing cocktails at the bar. Expensive but recommended.

MUnaJtJ4pmE79OtqfHSmYQ.text: After reading many reviews and high ratings I chose this to be my one stop while I was in London, and have to say that I was terribly disappointed!  At first it seemed almost impossible to get a table for the night, unless we wanted to dine at 6pm or after 11pm.  With persistence however, we managed to reserve a 9pm table.Some food items were impressive, like the tandoori prawns and black pepper chicken, and the duck was very creative.  Others were decent, but not necessarily exciting - goat cheese peppers, and mango papaya salad.  We were given four condiments earlier on to add to the meals as needed, and frankly this was gimmicky and even a bit insulting to the patrons (I think most people these days are much more savvier about food and flavors).  The items did nothing to accentuate the plates or palettes!   The most annoying part of the evening was that our food was continuously being rushed to the table.  We even asked the kitchen to slow things down as we wanted to enjoy our wine, food and conversation.  We were told that this wasn't possible because the staff wanted to go home! WHAT!!!We spoke to the manager and he reiteritated the same sentiment!  We thought he'd prefer the  feedback personally however, he urged us to go online and once again was indifferent to our disposition.  It was very obvious that our experience was irrelevant to his need for sending the staff home.  Interestingly enough, what would they have done if I had accepted the 11:15 or even 11:30 reservation?In addition, our overall food service was quite mediocre.  Half the time we didn't know who the waiter was.  We asked for some spice to heat things up, and were given quite a bland sauce - isn't this an indian restaurant??Given the prices, inconsistency in serving great food, and much to be desired in terms of service, it is incredibly surprising to see the restaurant has received a Michelin star.If you have one night in London, a place known for it's incredible culinary options, DON"T WASTE IT AT AMAYA!!

7absFpHWSUUqh1EIrIo8JQ.text: Finally, back in London after a 3 year stretch in the states, and I can enjoy the incredible restaurants here again!! Amaya is the balls!! I typically insist on having the tasting menus at new restaurants just to be able to get in as many of the specialities as I can and taste their range of dishes. Amaya makes this possible by serving most of the dishes tapas style. I went with a regular to Amaya who wasn't a very big eater. We chose 8 plates, 1 piece of naan each, and no rice, which turned out to be suitably filling. Had it just been my wife and I, we probably would have been satisfied with 10 dishes. We're fairly voluminous eaters (when no one else is around, then we scale in back a teeny bit!)The most memorable dishes were the Venison Seekh kebab (succulent, beautifully spiced, the guy I was with hadn't eaten meat in 10 years, but he still tried it and loved it), the Scallops on the half shell (in an absolutely delicious green curry), the pepper chicken tikka, the grilled jumbo prawns with I think a marsala marinade, the aubergine grilled with a tamarind type marinade (I may have got that wrong, but it tasted delicious) and the chicken joint. The green mango and raw papaya salad was also very very good.Followed by another couple of their martinis made for a superb lunch. I didn't pay so I can't comment on the prices but I can't wait to go back with my wife and really tackle the menu!

ke2z2wP8UG9WTWwZ1YJnSQ.text: Bets Indian food I have ever had! This is not your curry house fare, but delicately prepared authentic Indian dishes like I have never had before. Service was excellent; you will not be disappointed.

83q2htkXgGq99FhxX8rxVQ.text: I absolutely love Indian food, but living in Los Angeles, just about all the Indian restaurants are the same.  So for my trip to London, I really wanted to experience something new in Indian food.  So when I got an email for 'restaurant week in London' (whatever that is), I thought it was the perfect opportunity to try some fine Indian dining in the city most well-renouned for the cuisine.  I looked for the most highly-rated Indian restaurant on Yelp that had a restaurant week promotion, and I arrived at Amaya.  We booked a 15 pound pre-fixe lunch special, which offered a choice of vegetarian or non-vegatarian.  I was hoping to go with the meatless option, as an aspiring vegetarian, but the only difference between the two options made the meatless choice unrealistic.  It was the same price, with mainly the same options, but a banana kabob in place of fish. All the items on the pre-fixe sampler plate were very flavorful and unique, exactly what I was searching for.  Even my jaded bf was very satisfied with the different options.  I could not tell you what exactly I was served, as details are never really important to me when trying something new, I just want to have an experience, and this was a very enjoyable experience.  The ambiance and service was first class, as well as the food and presentation. And despite the seemingly small portions, we were both very full by the end of the meal.The only problem I had was finding the restaurant.  Being a London virgin, it had completely slipped my mind that 'arcade' was in fact not a street name, but a pedestrian alley. So we circled around the block 3 times, even asking a policeman for help, to no avail.  Part of the problem is that the map on my iPod (even the cop got out his iPhone to help us out) shows the restaurant on the wrong side of the street.  I see that the address listed on Yelp is right, but the one I got from the restaurant week booking site was slightly different (15 Haikin Arcade-which google places on the wrong side of Motcomb Street).  There is an entrance to Haikin Arcade across the street from Waitrose, on Motcomb Street, as well as another entrance on Lowndes Street.  Just don't be an idiot like me, looking for street sign that says 'arcade', and use the address on Yelp, not '15 Haikin Arcade'.

JrCXamhnnTfJYdRkBZRVkA.text: Great restaurant.  It's in a brilliant location and the atmosphere is perfect.  The food was outstanding as was the drinks menu.  The cocktails I tried were nicely balanced and subtle.The only criticism and the reason it doesn't get five starts is because the service isn't up to scratch.  I had a waiter almost elbow me in the face and one of our party had to wait twenty minutes and ask four times for their drink.

2et6kKoxwYLs48dH0QKjyg.text: This place is awesome! The interior is wow and I enjoy it very much. The meals are great, I have this idea to try everyhing on the menu and I am almost there. Great place. DEfinitely recommended!

3IhCQ-vApzKPm-2JY7uF1Q.text: This was really good, unusual Indian food.  Think more grilled than saucy, although they do have a couple dishes that we tried that had delicious sauces.My slight hesitation comes from the fact that we had a person in our group who is allergic to peanuts and gluten.  We chose Indian food because typically Indian food does not use a lot of peanuts or gluten.  Unfortunately, when we mentioned those allergies to our waiter a lot of consternation ensued because apparently they use peanuts and gluten in a LOT of their dishes.  I guess they use flour to thicken sauces and put peanuts in a lot of their spices.  So if you have any allergies, be sure to let them know - maybe even ask before you make your reservation.They eventually produced a menu that indicated which dishes worked and which didn't, but it was a little stressful getting to that point.But if you don't have any food allergies, and have some money to burn on some good Indian food, by all means head to Amaya!

Z1JIU7aGcYNDvUVOx-9VQA.text: Being Indian, being able to cook Indian food and being experimental about different cuisines, I am not that keen to go to an Indian restaurant when I am eating out. That's the reason I had always been sceptical of going to Amaya. It was expensive and it was Indian food. I used to think - why go there when I can cook curry myself for a fraction of what I would have to shell out at this restaurant?! Boy, how WRONG was I!!!Having lived in London for more than 3yrs now, I can only feel ashamed that yesterday was the first time I went to Amaya. How do I describe it?! Mmmm. Let me try.My friend and I went there for dinner last night (Thursday). The ambience is nice, and upmarket. Well, it being in Knightsbrige, what else can one expect. We were lead to our tables, and given a pretty elaborate drinks and wine menu. I chose Mimosa (Champagne and Orange juice, for the uninitiated) and my friend ordered a glass of rose wine. My drink was very smooth, but wasn't too dilute as well. Next came the dinner menu. We ordered a bunch of stuff - from Venison Kebabs to Fish Tikkas to Lamb. What is surprising about this place is that there isn't much when it comes to gravy-based stuff, and that is a GOOD thing! We also ordered some standard items like daal, rice and bread (naan). With every meal, you also get something called 'Amaya Chutney'. It is basically 4-different items, which are essentially toppings for the stuff you order. These consist of a Plum Chutney, a Tomato Chutney, and two other dry 'powders' - one made of ground roasted peanuts and the other of rose petals and some spices. Trust me, these were one of the best and unique parts about this place. These are so frikkin tasty that it is indescribable!! The food items arrived and man! they were finger-licking delicious!! All the meat-based items melted in your mouth! They had been marinated so well!! All the items were very unique in their tastes, like nothing I had tried before. Even the standard item (daal) tasted very different. Loved the food, and the service was impeccable as well.And I can't finish this never-ending review by not describing the second drink I had. I don't remember what it was called - but it was described as Mojito and Berries in the menu. I am usually not a Mojito person, but I have never tasted a drink like this before. In one word, it was Perfect!! And it had magic pops in it as well!!! These are small crackery substances that 'pop' in your mouth! Phew! I could have drunk a hundred of those Mojitos. You gotta try this Berry Mojito when you go to Amaya!! Anyhow, to sum up, this place IS NOT TO BE MISSED!! The best Indian food I have had in London!

eVnDJS0c4g13057N70agrA.text: The best Indian food I have ever had!  You must go hear.  Atmosphere is great, they have a community table if you are solo.  Food is served small plates style so you can share of just order the small portion and have lots of different plates in one meal.  Dessert is great!  Get the pomegranite and passion fruit granita.  I can not say enough, go there now!

_eisMsJVb06r-eagUU8_NA.text: The food and decor here is absolutely mind-blowing. So many amazing flavors and spices. I'm not a giant fan of modern indian food, but this was a whole different story. yum yum yum
